DOC.HEAD: Christmas Dinner, Carols Planned for Wounded Troops
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two military hospitals treating more than 100 soldiers who suffered wounds while fighting in Panama were festooned with holiday decorations on Christmas Eve, as gifts poured in from around the country. ``Everybody's been sending them Christmas cards, flowers and fruit baskets,'' said Senior Airman Cynthia Fontenot of Lackland Air Force Base, where Wilford Hall Medical Center is located. ``There's cases of cookies, potato chips, chocolate candies, shaving cream, razors and different things.'' Twenty-five injured Army Rangers returned to Fort Lewis, Wash. Thirty more GI's were treated at a Fort Bragg Army hospital Sunday, bringing to 67 the number of servicemen brought back to North Carolina in time for the holidays. ``The wounds are not that serious. We're able to pretty quickly give them treatment,'' said Fort Bragg spokesman Doug Foster. ``Their morale is good.'' In San Antonio, 65 patients wounded in Panama were being treated at Wilford Hall and Brooke Army Medical Center across town at Fort Sam Houston was treating 47 soldiers, officials said. Cooks at both hospitals began preparing a traditional Christmas meal for the patients. The soldiers' relatives have been treated to free lodging and rental cars from local companies, Sgt. Maj. Raymond Morris said at Brooke. ``All this is really unsolicited. We have asked for nothing and we have received so many things,'' Morris said. About 20 families have used an assistance center at Brooke, he said. At Saturday night's San Antonio Spurs basketball game, the city's Chamber of Commerce asked for donations of sweatshirts and tennis shoes for the soldiers. The number donated could not immediately be determined and chamber officials did not return a phone call Sunday. Since Wednesday, 244 soldiers have been flown to San Antonio in seven transport planes. The latest were 11 patients flown in Sunday. Three died en route and one died after arriving. Dozens have been transferred to other military hospitals or released to their units, officials said. At Fort Bragg, the original estimate of 3,000 soldiers from that base still in Panama by Christmas Eve had been revised to 4,000. At Fort Lewis, one soldier, a foot in a cast, was asked how his mission in Panama City had gone. He smiled, and yelled back, ``It was great!'' ``To a man, they all want to get well and get back to their units,'' said Lt. Gen. Calvin A. H. Waller, commander of Fort Lewis and I Corps, who shook each soldier's hand as they returned. ``They are outstanding young Americans.'' Most of the injuries sustained by the members of the 2nd Ranger Battalion, 75th Regiment, were to the lower back and legs, caused from parachuting from C-141 transport planes at an altitude below 500 feet to avoid being detected by radar, said Capt. Martin Eckert, Fort Lewis spokesman. ``If they are considered to be fully recovered and forces are still needed in Panama, the soldiers would probably be sent back down,'' Eckert said.
